name: N-(hydroxymethyl)benzamide

The presence of a hydroxymethyl group (-CH2OH) is expected to lower the melting point relative to benzamide. The hydroxymethyl group introduces additional flexibility and lowers the symmetry of the molecule, which typically reduces the melting point because it can disrupt the crystalline lattice formation: -CH2OH effect approximately -30 to -35 (based on similar hydroxyalkyl substitutions on aromatic systems). Additionally, hydroxymethyl may participate in hydrogen bonding, but this effect is less predictable: hydroxyl (OH) can form hydrogen bonds but they don’t necessarily increase the melting point as they could either lead to a more ordered structure, or introduce disorder if they prevent effective packing. We estimate this effect to be around -5, due to competing effects in the solid phase (enhanced molecular interactions vs. steric hindrance and disruption of crystal packing). Summing up the effects, we get a total estimated decrease of approximately -35 to -40 degrees Celsius from the benzamide reference melting point.
